title: Summoner Specialist: Pros and Cons
body:
So, just today, Riot Stashu unveiled what could be the most unique rune they have shown that will be coming in preseason to date; that being Summoner Specialist.

What this rune allows you to do is to be able to switch out summoner spells in game. Each time you cast a summoner, you recieve a shard. Once you have 3 of these shards, you are then able to trade them in for a different summoner spell.

Just at first glance, you can tell that there are A METRIC TON of possibilities with this rune, but there are also plenty of problems that arise with it as well. In this thread, I'd like to do my best to list them all off, and give everyone something to brainstorm off of. I'll be going role by role, explaining what this rune can do in each one.

Shall we begin?

-----------

#Top Lane

To be completely honest, I do not see too many top laners taking this rune. While there could be some cases, you have to remember that people taking this rune are trading off offensive and defensive capability for utility. Carry top laners, like Fiora or Riven, would want something more damage orientated. While tank top laners, like Maokai or Cho'gath would want more survivability. However, there are still some things we can list.

##Pros

 * Allows carry top laners to start off with a more lane dominant summoner set up (such as with ignite or exhaust), and the ability to switch to teleport later in the game. This particularly helps split push orientated champs, such as Shen or Nasus.

 * Allows top laners to become something akin to a second jungler. If you're playing a team that has great onjective control, the top laner could switch teleport for smite, and make it nigh impossible for the enemy team to challenge you at objectives.

##Cons

 * The "second jungler" aspect could also be a problem. The top laner could start with smite, and while the bot lane is leashing for the actual jungler, the top laner (and potentially mid laner as well), could invade the enemy jungle, and challenge the first buff, potentially wrecking the enemy junglers game all together.

------------

#Jungle

Unlike top lane, I can actually see several cases where junglers take this rune, especially those junglers that struggle with  early clears.

##Pros

 * Allows some junglers to start with a summoner set up that allows them to easily clear their first set of camps. For example, taking heal or clarity, then switching it out for flash or ghost. This could also allow some champs that are not normally junglers to actually succeed in the jungle.

 * Allows junglers who are good at invading, like Nunu or Shaco, to have a variety of options while counter jungling their opponent, while still being able to have more reliable options later in the game.

 * Gives junglers the opportunity to trade out smite for teleport, opening up a very wide range of ganking opportunities. Evelynn and Zac have been notorious for being difficult to track and predict where they would come from for a gank. With this rune, any jungler could have that capability.

 * Gives junglers the option of more useful summoners during the later stages of the game when smite becomes less useful, especially when both Baron and Elder Dragon are down.

##Cons

 * This problem isn't entirely aimed at junglers, per se, but more so jungle *items*. This rune allows laners to start with smite, and get the cost efficient jungle items, while still being able to switch out Smite and keeping the jungle items. This could lead us into another "Mid Ezeral Smite" meta with things like Devourer Twitch, or Cinderhulk Top Maokai. This is one of the more glaring problems this rune has, and Riot is aware of it. They have yet to figure out a proper solution, though.

 * This rune can allow an entire team to take Smite, and take onjectives *ludicrously* fast. While this is a more extreme case, it is still possible.

--------------------

#Mid Lane

Like top lane, I doubt we will see many mid laners take this rune, since there are simply better options. But...

##Pros

 * Allows mid laners to better react to the situation. If tbey are losing lane quite heavily, they can opt into more defensive options, such as heal or barrier. If they are winning, they could opt into ignite or releport. 

 * Some mid laners could opt into clarity with this rune, making their laning phase much easier, such as Taliyah or Lux.

##Cons

 * Could make hard matchups in mid lane even harder, due to the number of options your opponent could have in order to counter you, or shut you down even harder.

 * Could make mid lane roams even more impactful than they are now, which would allow mid laners to easily pressure the map in a multitude of ways.

--------------

#Bot Lane

Out of any of the roles, I suspect you'll see this rune on marksmen the least. They need the damage, and speccing into utility makes them more of a liability than an asset.

In fact, I suspect that this will be so rare, that I won't even list off any pros or cons. For if you are to see this on a bot lane marksmen, you're either being cheesed, or the person is new, and doesn't know what their doing.

------------

#Support

Out of all of the roles, support is most likely where you will see this rune end up. There are so many things you could do with this rune, its uncanny.

##Pros

 * Allows week laning supports, such as Janna or Nami, to opt into summoners that make the lane easier on them, such as clarity or heal, while still having the option to opt into a more reliable mid to late game such as exhaust or ghost.

 * Allows lane dominant supports, such as Leona or Alistar, to opt out of aggressive options like ignite, and take things like teleport or exhaust once out of lane.

 * Allows high damage supports, like Brand or Zyra, to actually opt into clairvoyance for early vision, that way they can spend their gold on more useful stats in lane.

 * Because of supports, this rune could very well make the 2 least used summoners in the game, clarity and clairvoyance, actually viable early game choices. EDIT: MY BAD!!! Completely forgot clairvoyance doesnt exist anymore,  and clarity isn't on SR. Woops.



 * Similar to top laners, supports can also opt into smite, and help with objective control.

##Cons

 * Similar to top laners, supports could also become "second unglers", and challenge, and potentially ruin, the enemy jungler's day.

--------------

As you can see, there is ALOT that this rune brings to the table, but it also brings about its own share of problems as well. Remember, that this rune is still in development, and may very well drastically change come preseason.

If you guys have any questions, I will try my best to answer any and all of them. Otherwise, I hope you enjoyed this, and I'd love to hear any thoughts you guys might have.

Electro

replies.body:
Nice write up, your assessment of opportunity cost in particular. That matches pretty well with what we've seen in testing so far, where a lot of the stuff that sounds like it could be overbearing at first glance ends up ok, or even weak, because of how valuable the other runes you're giving up are.

Also worth noting that Clarity's not available on SR and CV's been gone for a while now, so while Summoner Specialist's probably appealing to a number of supports those won't be part of the appeal for them.

Here's a question: Does it work with smite?

Because smite can be cast quite rapidly compared to other spells, meaning you could start smite, smite 2-ish times and have crystals ready.
We're still figuring out smite interactions, will likely need some degree of special rules for it.

What if you made the Summoner Spells give a number of Crystals equal to its cooldown or something?

The only downside I could see is that it would lead to some feel-bad moments where you're just a few crystals off.

Something in that line's an option and would give us a tuning lever. Wouldn't necessarily tie it one to one with CD, allowing some degree of taking shorter CD spells to allow more swaps seems like good play provided it doesn't dominate other choices.
I recommend preventing smite from being switched out. It will create far too many problems.

Agreed, especially if you purchase a jungle item. It'd be unfair to let a {{champion:96}} with {{item:1416}} to run around with flash and ghost kiting everyone and not being killable and giving you less means of escape.

They could try setting a higher amount of shards to switch, and then assigning each summoner spell a certain value when used. Say it's 10 to switch a summoner, Smite gives 1 shard per use, flash gives 4, Heal gives 2 etc.
Maybe do +1 Crystal for smite and making it +3 Crystals for other Summoners Spells, costing 9 to change.

Could you make it similar to how kayn fills his orb for his transformation, but instead base it on percent of CD for that sum spell? That may/may not normalize the value assigned to purchasing a summoner spell based on it's CD and the CD of the spell used to trade it in?

You can try making them change into baby versions of the summoner spells.

It can even be like if you swap back to a spell you started the game with you still keep the better one just ones you didn't start with are weaker.

Say if you didn't start with flash, and you switch to it later in the game. The flash cool down in something like 6 or 7 mins and not 5.

If you switch to smite it only has 70% of the damage compared to someone who started with it and you can't buy jungle items.

Ignite does magic damage instead of true damage.

Heal only targets a ally. Barrier only shields you for 1 second.

Teleport is only half the map in range.

Cleanse doesn't give 65% cc reduction, and exhaust doesn't slow.

It will also keep your starting summoner spells as important as they are now because no matter how many times you change your spells they will still be the big ones.Losing toplane, switch to barrier or something, then after that, switch back to the full power teleport because you started the lane with Teleport. If you think you need a full power barrier start that then have to deal with the weak teleport later.

If I could swap it out later and use it only during laning I would definately opt into it.

What are your thoughts on this idea Meddler? I'd love to hear it.
How do you skip Morello in favor of damage when it gives 100 AP?
Never understood why people think Morello doesnt give much damage. 100 AP is a lot, and 20% cdr could be seen as up to 20% more DPS (though that'd require spamming off cooldown).

You could take Luden's Echo instead, offering the passive's bonus damage as well as movement speed, replacing the mana and cooldown for a more burst oriented style.

You could also rush gunblade, without needing to worry about mana gunblade would give you lane sustain and the powerful active, albeit the cost of 20 AP.

And some could take Liandry's Torment or rylai's first if it has good synergy with their kit (malzahar, taliyah, etc)

It very much depends on the champion and their capability. Forcing morello's first item may not always be beneficial to them.

Although the AP is fine, It's just that I get so much more for my champions with another item.

Let's take Taliyah for example, rylais is a core item on her. I'd love to rush it over morellos for the slow.

Another example is Ziggs who may want to rush a ludens echo with the hope of bursting his lane down.

You've talked about how important it is to have levers on these runes to buff or nerf them when their power level is off. How would that work with this Rune in particular? You could change the number of casts required, but i I don't feel like that would affect the power of it too much since you'd likely only want to switch once or twice during a game anyways.

There'll be some form of passive bonus attached to the rune as well in this case (currently that's summoner CD reduction). That's there both as a tuning lever and because without it the rune's been testing as quite weak. Cost to swap's the other main lever as you mention. I'd expect those to be enough, if not could also do something like give a brief stats bonus on any summoner spell cast. Don't think that'll be necessary though here and it does add extra complexity for likely low value.

Meddler, why is it that every single one of these runes I've seen just feels like some kind of gimmick?  they are either super situational/conditional, or just have so little impact and use that it just feels like regular old stats would be better.

WIll these runes have aram taken into account, I'd love being able to swap out clarity when i don't need it anymore but at the same time you could just take snowball get early kills then swap to ignite or something after you are ahead on first death. 

my point is will there be an exception to snowball where it takes more uses to proc

First off, I actually like this overall.  It's reminiscent of one of the things I love about the game SMITE (you pick your summoner spells in game, not pre-game, and you don't get your second one until mid game).

I also think that most of the options seem pretty balanced even without knowing what most of the other runes are.

I agree with your comment further down about possibly needing special interactions for smite.  The option to start smite and invade on the opposite side of mid from where your jungler is starting being at least 'OK' and not overbearing sounds like a serious red flag to me.  Factoring in the chance of the enemy jungler being on that side already or the enemy laners on that side intervening, I'd estimate it's a roughly 30% chance of automatic success (that is, maybe 30% of the time there will be nobody contesting you stealing the buff, since you've got a theoretical 50% chance of the jungler starting there and I see people ward about 40% of the time on the side their jungler isn't starting).  Even if both sides do this, there's still a significant lane advantage to having the buff going into lane (especially if it's blue buff).  If only one side does this, they've got an insane early advantage that can very easily decide the game in the current meta.

Additionally, I think you should be keeping an eye on interactions with mark on ARAM.  That has an even lower CD and is very powerful if used right early in the game, and also has the re-cast gimmick to factor in.

The sad thing is the OP thinks that Clarity is available on SR...

I wish they'd put it back on SR (changing it like they did heal would be good too imo).

That was my mistake. I completely forgot that it isn't.

If it were to come back, though, this rune would open it up to mid laners and supports.

A majority of the "Pros" you have listed honestly feel like enormous cons to me in terms of game balance / health. For example, 

"Allows top laners to become something akin to a second jungler. If you're playing a team that has great onjective control, the top laner could switch teleport for smite, and make it nigh impossible for the enemy team to challenge you at objectives."

This sounds like an absolute nightmare to play against, and there is very little that can be done about it, it has the potential to cause a lot of really weird smite arms-races in the early game and abuse of jungle xp forcing lane advantages. 

"Gives junglers the opportunity to trade out smite for teleport, opening up a very wide range of ganking opportunities. Evelynn and Zac have been notorious for being difficult to track and predict where they would come from for a gank. With this rune, any jungler could have that capability."

Any jungler having that capability is not healthy for the game, junglers are balanced around the very notion of their available gank paths. Characters with strong early game clears / special gank routes usually suffer from weaker lategames or other abusable downsides to prevent them from being OP... If any character could get those special gank routes and still be able to swap back to flash later on we're going to run into some big balance issues.

"Allows lane dominant supports, such as Leona or Alistar, to opt out of aggressive options like ignite, and take things like teleport"

This sounds cool but in reality I could see it being used at higher MMR to outright kill split pushing and characters who rely on applying heavy lane pressure...

I hope this is just a gut reaction, but it feels to me like it is going to cause so many weird balancing issues.

If this keystone is too strong and is used effectively, it's going to cause an arms-race where you can't win your lane without it because the enemy top laner for instance is gonna be running offensive summoners and still have teleport for the lategame.

If the keystone is too weak due to other keystones being better choices, then there is no point in Summoner Specialist to exist, because it falls into being an awkward cheese gimmick that leaves you, and by extension your team, at a disadvantage the rest of the game.

Maybe i'm just being dramatic, I hope I am, but I can't envision this being fun to play against, or good for the game. 

It's an interesting quirky thing, but I don't think it has -any- business being in the game, personally.

Respect other peoples opinions on it though, I hope it works out in the end regardless.
